Free University Attracts Six Hundred
By STEVE BUCKINGHAM
The fact that the Baltimore Free
University registered almost six hundred
people last Sunday opened a question for
its leadership: "Can the Free University
remain free?"
Breaking with its past policy of not asking its students for money, the FU leaders requested a two dollar donation at
registration. According
to
Dennis
Khrone, one of the organizer, the contributions are to be used primarily for
printing the catalogue. The more money,
he implied, the better the catalogue.
James May, one of the teachers and
money collectors, said that about half of
the people paid at registration and most
of the others stated their intentions to
pay later.
When asked about the number of people
participating in the programs this semester, !throne stated that there were many
more people than expected. The largest
portion of the 580 students were from the
community, students were the next most
numerous and several older people
rounded out the group. That so many
people participated, Khrone declared,
testifies that the Free University is a
viable "alternative" to the more structured education provided by other institutions.

Guitars to Weaving
The subjects available at the Free
University range from the occult (or
courses") to "socio-pro"esoteric

blematic courses," to such general courses as guitar instruction and hand weaving.
Among the "esoteric" subjects offered are astrology, ESP development,
"esoteric Buddhism," and "esoteric
science." There are two "socio-problematic" courses: one on Communism
and one on the history of the class
struggle.
The basic philosophy of the Free
University cannot be easily explained.
Khrone described the institution as one
in which "anybody could learn and anyone could teach." He felt, as did May,
that it was a way of organizing people
for learning as an alternative to "normal" college instruction. As May stated, "There is a minimal amount of
organization to get a maximum of people
involved."

No Grades
The advantages of an unstructured
set of courses are many, May remarked. The classes are held in scattered
locations: at Levering Hall, at the Theosophic Society and in private homes.
The students are from various areas
and backgrounds; they bring with them
a wide variety of feelings and attitudes.
There are no credits given, and no
grades, which eliminates competition.
"People can speak frankly in classes,"
he said, and those who come have a
genuine desire to learn." These things,
believe the leaders of the Free University, are qualities lacking in institutions including Hopkins.

The Baltimore Free University attracted almost 600 persons last Sunday through their promises
of providing an alternative to structured university courses. However, inflation has caused the
Free University to cost $2 for participants.

Pollution Put on the Defensive
or is it?
After 355 days in office, President Nixon finally got around to his longawaited public statement on the country's pollution crisis. Compared to
some of the President's other long-awaited policy statements, it is a highly
laudable document, considering the fact that he has spent so much time
preparing it; however, it leaves a great deal to be desired.
Why, for instance, do Nixon's proposed expenditures for future combat ing of pollution actually total less than those allotted for coming fiscal
year? This fact is markedly incompatible with his statements that the current proposal is more broadly-based and far-reaching than legislation enacted under the Johnson administration. Furthermore, there is presently a bill
in the Senate calling for expenditures of $25 billion over the next five
years. Nixon justifies his figure of $10 billion over four years with: "This
will provide every community that needs it with secondary waste treaytment
in areas of special need, including communities on the Great Lakes." This is
a far cry from every community's general needs.
Why, too, is there no mention, in the entire document, of the complex
problems caused by the airplane? Is there perhaps a governmental conflictof-interest in the fact that the supersonic jets now being financed by Washington will cause unacceptable amounts of air and noise pollution? Why, for
example, should towns like Glen Burnie'spend great amounts of money and
effort for proper waste treatment if the town will be psychologically
destroyed by Friendship Airport?
Significantly, the President's message also lacked any mention of the
subject of oil pollution by offshore drilling and dockside leakage, despite
the fact that it was one of the first crises to confront his administration.
Is it possible that big business will continue to get a major say in who gets
hit by Nixon's legislation and who doesn't? After all, massive federal
intervention is quite a surprise under a Republican government.
Unquestionably, many of,the President's proposals will prove helpful and
beneficial. It is encouraging that he has declared that $327 million will be
spent this year alone on the purchase and improvement of parks and
recreational areas. His concern with the content and quality of automobile
fuels is surprising, as in his emphasis on the possibilities and necessity of reusing and reprocessing waste materials. Perhaps most promising is his proposal that violations be quickly and effectively brought to court and that
the courts be allowed to fine non-compliers at the prohibitive rate of
$10,000 per day.
With some of these progressive signs, it is to be earnestly hoped that
future messages will assure more powerful and well-coordinated attack on
one of this country's most pressing problems. One of Nixon's statements in
particular gives rise to speculation as to whether he really understands the
gravity of the situation: "Water pollution has three principal sources...Some
of these are nature's own pollutions. The Missouri River was known as
'Big Muddy'long before towns and industries were built on its banks."

Pollution Put on the Defensive
or is it?
After 355 days in office, President Nixon finally got around to his longawaited public statement on the country's pollution crisis. Compared to
some of the President's other long-awaited policy statements, it is a highly
laudable document, considering the fact that he has spent so much time
preparing it; however, it leaves a great deal to be desired.
Why, for instance, do Nixon's proposed expenditures for future combat ing of pollution actually total less than those allotted for coming fiscal
year? This fact is markedly incompatible with his statements that the current proposal is more broadly-based and far-reaching than legislation enacted under the Johnson administration. Furthermore, there is presently a bill
in the Senate calling for expenditures of $25 billion over the next five
years. Nixon justifies his figure of $10 billion over four years with: "This
will provide every community that needs it with secondary waste treaytment
in areas of special need, including communities on the Great Lakes." This is
a far cry from every community's general needs.
Why, too, is there no mention, in the entire document, of the complex
problems caused by the airplane? Is there perhaps a governmental conflictof-interest in the fact that the supersonic jets now being financed by Washington will cause unacceptable amounts of air and noise pollution? Why, for
example, should towns like Glen Burnie'spend great amounts of money and
effort for proper waste treatment if the town will be psychologically
destroyed by Friendship Airport?
Significantly, the President's message also lacked any mention of the
subject of oil pollution by offshore drilling and dockside leakage, despite
the fact that it was one of the first crises to confront his administration.
Is it possible that big business will continue to get a major say in who gets
hit by Nixon's legislation and who doesn't? After all, massive federal
intervention is quite a surprise under a Republican government.
Unquestionably, many of,the President's proposals will prove helpful and
beneficial. It is encouraging that he has declared that $327 million will be
spent this year alone on the purchase and improvement of parks and
recreational areas. His concern with the content and quality of automobile
fuels is surprising, as in his emphasis on the possibilities and necessity of reusing and reprocessing waste materials. Perhaps most promising is his proposal that violations be quickly and effectively brought to court and that
the courts be allowed to fine non-compliers at the prohibitive rate of
$10,000 per day.
With some of these progressive signs, it is to be earnestly hoped that
future messages will assure more powerful and well-coordinated attack on
one of this country's most pressing problems. One of Nixon's statements in
particular gives rise to speculation as to whether he really understands the
gravity of the situation: "Water pollution has three principal sources...Some
of these are nature's own pollutions. The Missouri River was known as
'Big Muddy'long before towns and industries were built on its banks."

This year's Mardi Gras has been the drunkest and the
most violent in many years. Scores have been arrested
for robbery, fighting and carrying weapons. More than

Dow 7-'Guilty'
Seven of the members of an anti-war group that destroyed files and equipment at the Washington offices of the Dow
Chemical Company last March have been found guilty on
two counts of malicious destruction of property and one of
unlawful entry.
The charges followed a raid on Dow's offices when the
group--which includes four priests and a nun--poured
human blood on papers and furniture, and threw files out
of a fourth-story window.
Throughout the six-day trial, the defendants were repeatedly silenced by Judge John H. Pratt when they tried
to explain their feelings that what they did was necessary. Two of the original nine defendants changed their
pleas from innocent to no-contest midway through the
trial, claiming that the proceedings were dehumanizing.
Three of the defendants and one of their attorneys were
cited for contempt.
Last Friday, there was a scuffle between spectators,
marshals, and one of the defendants. The defendant was
cited for contempt. In his summation, Tuesday,one of the
defendants told the jury, "To destroy property that has
no right to exist is not violence. You have to decide whether what we did was to commit a crime or to stop a
crime."
The jury decided in less than 45 minutes.

Maritime Flushes
The captain of the Japanese ore carrier California
Maru refused to leave his sinking ship and smiled and
waved as the boat vanished into stormy Pacific waters.
The captain, Hiroshi Sumimura, 44, was one of five
men missing when the carrier sank in rough seas about
250 miles east of Tokyo. The remaining 24 crewmen
were rescued by New Zealand and Japanese vessels. The
four missing sailors left the ship in its lone undamaged
lifeboat.
Survivors prasied Capt. Sumimura for his bravery and
said he had kept them aboard the sinking vessel until
rescue was near, rather than let them jump into the cold,
rough sea. "It was a long wait until we saw an approaching ship's light," one man said.
After seeing the men safely onto the life rafts the captain refused to abandon ship. "He smiled and waved his
hands to us before the ship sank," survivors said.
In other maritime news, a sea and air search for victims of an alleged explosion aboard a launch in Venezualan coastal waters was called off today when authorities
determined the report was a hoax.
Authorities began an immediate investigation into the
identity or identities of suspected amateur radio operators who broadcast a string of messages last night reporting the explosion.

Texas said Wednesday that the world's third largest
telescope was only minimally damaged when an astronomer went berserk and shot seven pistol bullets into it.
"It will not bother astronomical observations at all,
Dr. Harlan Smith said. "In fact, we were back in observation Friday night, the day of the shooting."
Smith said the 107-inch telescope would require no
repairs, "because the damage is so localized that
it's equivalent to the mirror being very dirty."
